A 'timing belt', or 'cam belt' (informal usage), is a part of an internal
combustion engine that controls the timing of the engine's valves. Some engines,
such as the flat-4 Volkswagen air-cooled engine, and the straight-6 Toyota F
engine use timing gears. First seen in the 1954 Devin, which won the SCCA
National Championship in 1956 (see May 1957 Sports Cars Illustrated article by O
C Rich), timing belts replaced the older style timing chains that were common
until the 1970s and 1980s (although in the last decade there has been
reemergence of chain use for many carmakers). Some manufacturers, such as BMW [http://www.usautoparts.net/bmw/parts/bmw-timing-chain-
world.htm BMW Timing Chain - BMW World] and Mercedes-
Benz, [http://www.partsgeek.com/mparts/timing_chain/mercedes.html Mercedes
Timing Chain - Timing Chains] are known for using timing chains because of
their durability. The term "timing belt" is sometimes used for the more general
case of any flat belt with integral teeth, although such usage is a misnomer
since there is no timing or synchronization involved.
